p: Recombinant vector vaccines can be defined as live, dividing viruses that are genetically manipulated to harbor some additional pathogenic gene, coding for foreign proteins, responsible for eliciting immune response [ 82]. Recombinant vector vaccines are highly efficient in triggering an immune response as they can infect cells and sustain in the body for quite a long time and can react to antigen-presenting cells directly. Also viral proteins in such vaccines can act like adjuvant [ 83], thereby enhancing immune response, resulting in generating more antibodies and long-term immunity, and reducing the dose of antigen required. Several attempts have been made in the direction of the development of SARS-coronavirus (SARS-CoV) vaccine for which various viral vectors are genetically engineered to express SARS-CoV proteins in them. Adenovirus and modified vaccinia virus Ankara (MVA) are the two most common viral vectors used in the development of SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV vaccines.
